snippet: Experts were poring over military radar data that seemed to indicate that the missing Malaysian flight had turned west and stayed aloft long after its last contact with ground controllers.
abstract: Official says investigators are examining data seeming to show that missing Malaysia Airlines jetliner was still in automated communication with satellite systems, and may therefore still have been airborne, for hours after ground controllers last heard from it; information adds to growing belief that jet turned off course after contact was lost and could have flown hundreds of miles west.

byline.original: By MATTHEW L. WALD and THOMAS FULLER
byline.contributor: Matthew L. Wald reported from Washington and Thomas Fuller from Sepang, Malaysia. Reporting was contributed by Michael Forsythe from Sepang, Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley from Hong Kong, Alan Cowell from London, Gardiner Harris from New Delhi and Christopher Drew, Thom Shanker and Eric Schmitt from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Experts were poring over military radar data that seemed to indicate that the missing Malaysian flight had turned west and stayed aloft long after its last contact with ground controllers.

headline.main: Jet Hunt Shifts as Findings Hint at Longer Flight
headline.print_headline: Jet Hunt Shifts After Data Hints at Longer Flight
